statutes.name: Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA)
statutes.description: U.S. federal anti-hacking law that prohibits unauthorized access to protected computers.
sections: 18 U.S.C. § 1030(a)(1) - Espionage and national security information
18 U.S.C. § 1030(a)(2) - Unauthorized access to obtain information
statutes.penalties: Fines and imprisonment up to 20 years for repeat offenses
statutes.notes: Broadly interpreted, CFAA has been criticized for its vague language and potential to criminalize common computer use.

statutes.name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
statutes.description: EU regulation on data protection and privacy for all individuals within the European Union and the European Economic Area.
articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')
statutes.penalties: Up to €20 million or 4% of annual global turnover, whichever is higher
statutes.notes: GDPR sets strict requirements for data handling and includes significant penalties for non-compliance.

statutes.name: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA)
statutes.description: California statute intended to enhance privacy rights and consumer protection for residents of California.
provisions: Right to know what personal information is collected
Right to opt-out of the sale of personal information
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to $2,500 per violation or $7,500 for intentional violations
statutes.notes: Often compared to GDPR, CCPA introduced similar data privacy concepts to U.S. law.

statutes.name: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA)
statutes.description: Federal law that criminalizes production and dissemination of technology intended to circumvent copyright protection measures.
sections: 17 U.S.C. § 512 - Safe harbor provisions for online service providers
17 U.S.C. § 1201 - Circumvention of copyright protection systems
statutes.penalties: Criminal penalties up to $1 million and 10 years imprisonment
statutes.notes: Provides framework for copyright protection in digital environments while balancing innovation and content protection.

statutes.name: Electronic Communications Privacy Act (ECPA)
statutes.description: Federal law extending government restrictions on wire taps to include transmissions of electronic data by computer.
titles: Title II - Stored Communications Act (18 U.S.C. § 2701-2712)
statutes.notes: Considered outdated by many legal experts due to rapid technological advancement since 1986.

statutes.name: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
statutes.description: Federal law that provides data privacy and security provisions for safeguarding medical information.
key_rules: Privacy Rule - protects individually identifiable health information
Security Rule - sets standards for protecting electronic health information
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to $1.5 million per incident; criminal penalties up to $250,000 and 10 years imprisonment
statutes.notes: Applies to protected health information (PHI) in electronic, paper, and oral forms.

statutes.name: Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA)
statutes.description: Federal law that regulates the online collection of personal information from children under 13 years of age.
requirements: Parental consent for collection, use, or disclosure of personal information
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to $43,792 per violation
statutes.notes: Requires verifiable parental consent before collecting personal information from children.

statutes.name: CAN-SPAM Act
statutes.full_name: Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography And Marketing Act
statutes.description: Federal law that establishes requirements for commercial email messages and gives recipients the right to stop emails.
statutes.penalties: Up to $43,792 per email in violation
statutes.notes: Preempts most state laws but allows states to enforce laws prohibiting deceptive practices.

statutes.name: Computer Misuse Act
statutes.description: UK law that criminalizes unauthorized access to computer systems and data.
offenses: Section 1 - Unauthorized access to computer material
Section 2 - Unauthorized access with intent to commit further offenses
statutes.penalties: Up to 10 years imprisonment for the most serious offenses
statutes.notes: Served as a model for similar legislation in other Commonwealth countries.

statutes.name: Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA)
statutes.description: Canadian federal privacy law governing how private sector organizations collect, use and disclose personal information.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to CAD $100,000
statutes.notes: Applies to commercial activities across Canada, with some provinces having substantially similar legislation.

statutes.name: Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act (CISA)
statutes.description: Federal law encouraging cybersecurity information sharing between government and private sector entities.
key_provisions: Legal protections for sharing cyber threat information
statutes.notes: Aims to improve cybersecurity through enhanced information sharing while addressing privacy concerns.

statutes.name: Network and Information Security Directive (NIS Directive)
statutes.description: EU directive on security of network and information systems across the Union.
key_requirements: Security requirements for operators of essential services
statutes.notes: First piece of EU-wide cybersecurity legislation, succeeded by NIS2 Directive in 2022.

statutes.name: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA)
statutes.description: Federal law that requires financial institutions to explain information-sharing practices and safeguard sensitive data.
statutes.notes: Applies to companies that are 'significantly engaged' in providing financial services.

statutes.name: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX)
statutes.description: Federal law that established auditing and financial regulations for public companies, including IT controls.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to $5 million and 20 years imprisonment for executives
statutes.notes: While not specifically an IT law, SOX has significant implications for IT governance and security in public companies.

statutes.name: Stored Communications Act (SCA)
statutes.description: Part of ECPA that governs privacy expectations in stored electronic communications.
statutes.penalties: Fines and imprisonment up to 5 years
statutes.notes: Creates framework for government access to electronic communications held by third parties.

statutes.name: Video Privacy Protection Act (VPPA)
statutes.description: Federal law that governs the privacy of video rental and purchase records.
key_provisions: Prohibition on disclosure of personally identifiable information
statutes.penalties: Civil damages and attorney fees
statutes.notes: Originally focused on video stores, now applies to digital streaming services.

statutes.name: Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA)
statutes.description: Federal law that restricts telephone solicitations and the use of automated telephone equipment.
key_restrictions: Text messages to cell phones without consent
statutes.penalties: Up to $1,500 per violation
statutes.notes: Frequently updated to address new technologies and communication methods.

statutes.name: Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA)
statutes.description: Federal law that regulates the collection, dissemination, and use of consumer information, including consumer credit information.
key_provisions: Consumer rights to access credit reports
Permissible purposes for accessing credit information
statutes.penalties: Civil damages and criminal penalties up to $5,000
statutes.notes: Applies to background check companies and credit reporting agencies.

statutes.name: Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act (E-SIGN)
statutes.description: Federal law that grants legal recognition to electronic signatures and records in interstate and foreign commerce.
statutes.notes: Works in conjunction with state Uniform Electronic Transactions Acts (UETA).

statutes.name: Driver's Privacy Protection Act (DPPA)
statutes.description: Federal law that governs the privacy and disclosure of personal information gathered by state motor vehicle departments.
key_provisions: Restrictions on disclosure of personal information
statutes.penalties: Civil damages up to $2,500 per violation
statutes.notes: Applies to state DMV databases and their commercial use.

statutes.name: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS)
statutes.description: Industry security standard for organizations that handle branded credit cards.
statutes.notes: Not a law but a contractual obligation for merchants accepting credit cards.

statutes.name: Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA)
statutes.description: Federal law that provides a comprehensive framework for ensuring the effectiveness of information security controls over federal information systems.
statutes.notes: Applies to federal agencies and their contractors handling federal information systems.

statutes.name: Wiretap Act
statutes.description: Federal law that regulates the interception of electronic communications.
statutes.penalties: Up to 5 years imprisonment and $250,000 fine
statutes.notes: Part of the broader Electronic Communications Privacy Act framework.

statutes.name: Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)
statutes.description: Federal law that protects the privacy of student education records.
key_provisions: Right to request amendment of records
statutes.penalties: Withdrawal of federal education funding
statutes.notes: Applies to all schools that receive funds under an applicable program of the U.S. Department of Education.

statutes.name: Cybersecurity Enhancement Act
statutes.description: Federal law that promotes cybersecurity research and development and workforce development.
statutes.notes: Focuses on improving national cybersecurity through research and collaboration.

statutes.name: Cybersecurity Act of 2015 (CISA)
statutes.description: Federal law that facilitates cybersecurity information sharing between the private sector and government.
statutes.notes: Encourages sharing of cyber threat indicators and defensive measures.

statutes.name: Digital Services Act (DSA)
statutes.description: EU regulation establishing harmonized rules on the provision of digital services in the internal market.
statutes.penalties: Up to 6% of annual worldwide turnover
statutes.notes: Complements the Digital Markets Act in regulating digital platforms.

statutes.name: Digital Markets Act (DMA)
statutes.description: EU regulation aimed at ensuring fair and open digital markets by preventing unfair practices by gatekeepers.
statutes.penalties: Up to 10% of annual worldwide turnover
statutes.notes: Targets large digital platforms designated as 'gatekeepers'.

statutes.name: NIS2 Directive
statutes.description: Updated EU directive on security of network and information systems, replacing the original NIS Directive.
statutes.penalties: Up to €10 million or 2% of annual worldwide turnover
statutes.notes: Significantly strengthens the EU's cybersecurity resilience.

statutes.name: Artificial Intelligence Act (AI Act)
statutes.description: EU regulation establishing harmonized rules for artificial intelligence systems.
statutes.penalties: Up to €35 million or 7% of annual worldwide turnover
statutes.notes: World's first comprehensive AI regulation framework.

statutes.name: Virginia Consumer Data Protection Act (VCDPA)
statutes.description: Virginia's comprehensive consumer data privacy law.
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to $7,500 per violation
statutes.notes: Second state after California to enact comprehensive privacy legislation.

statutes.name: Colorado Privacy Act (CPA)
statutes.description: Colorado's comprehensive consumer data privacy law.
consumer_rights: Right to opt out of data processing
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to $20,000 per violation
statutes.notes: Includes unique provisions for profiling and automated decision-making.

statutes.name: Connecticut Data Privacy Act (CTDPA)
statutes.description: Connecticut's comprehensive consumer data privacy law.
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to $5,000 per violation
statutes.notes: Similar structure to Virginia and Colorado privacy laws.

statutes.name: Utah Consumer Privacy Act (UCPA)
statutes.description: Utah's consumer data privacy law with a more business-friendly approach.
consumer_rights: Right to opt out of data processing
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties determined by state attorney general
statutes.notes: Notable for not including a private right of action for consumers.

statutes.name: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA)
statutes.description: Illinois law regulating the collection, use, and storage of biometric information.
key_requirements: Written consent before collecting biometric data
Disclosure of storage and destruction timelines
statutes.penalties: $1,000-$5,000 per violation plus attorney fees
statutes.notes: One of the strictest biometric privacy laws in the US, frequently cited in class action lawsuits.

statutes.name: Texas Identity Theft Enforcement and Protection Act
statutes.description: Texas law governing the use of biometric identifiers and biometric information.
key_provisions: Notice requirements for biometric data collection
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to $25,000
statutes.notes: Similar to Illinois BIPA but with different enforcement mechanisms.

statutes.name: New York SHIELD Act
statutes.description: New York law requiring reasonable data security measures and breach notification.
key_requirements: Breach notification to state attorney general
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to $5,000 per violation
statutes.notes: Applies to any business that conducts business in New York and collects private information.

statutes.name: Massachusetts Data Protection Regulation (201 CMR 17.00)
statutes.description: Massachusetts regulation requiring comprehensive information security programs.
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties and private right of action
statutes.notes: One of the most comprehensive state data security laws in the US.

statutes.name: Washington Privacy Act
statutes.description: Proposed comprehensive privacy legislation in Washington state (multiple attempts, not yet enacted).
statutes.notes: Multiple versions have been proposed but not yet enacted into law.

statutes.name: Canada's Privacy Act
statutes.description: Federal law governing how federal government institutions collect, use, and disclose personal information.
key_provisions: Limits on collection of personal information
statutes.notes: Applies only to federal government institutions, not private sector.

statutes.name: Consumer Privacy Protection Act (Bill C-27)
statutes.description: Proposed Canadian federal privacy law to replace PIPEDA for private sector organizations.
statutes.notes: Currently under legislative review, would modernize Canadian privacy law.

statutes.name: Quebec Act Respecting the Protection of Personal Information in the Private Sector
statutes.description: Quebec's private sector privacy law, considered substantially similar to PIPEDA.
statutes.penalties: Administrative monetary penalties up to CAD $25 million
statutes.notes: Modernized in 2021 with GDPR-like provisions.

statutes.name: Alberta Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA)
statutes.description: Alberta's private sector privacy law governing collection, use and disclosure of personal information.
statutes.penalties: Administrative penalties up to CAD $100,000
statutes.notes: Considered substantially similar to PIPEDA.

statutes.name: British Columbia Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA)
statutes.description: British Columbia's private sector privacy law.
statutes.penalties: Administrative penalties up to CAD $100,000
statutes.notes: Considered substantially similar to PIPEDA.

statutes.name: Australia Privacy Act
statutes.description: Australian federal law governing the handling of personal information by Australian government agencies and private sector organizations.
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to AUD $50 million
statutes.notes: Applies to organizations with annual turnover of AUD $3 million or more.

statutes.name: New Zealand Privacy Act
statutes.description: New Zealand's comprehensive privacy law governing personal information handling.
statutes.penalties: Civil penalties up to NZD $10,000
statutes.notes: Significantly updated in 2020 with modern privacy protections.

statutes.name: Singapore Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
statutes.description: Singapore's comprehensive personal data protection law.
key_obligations: Consent for collection, use and disclosure
statutes.penalties: Financial penalties up to SGD $1 million
statutes.notes: Covers both private and public sector organizations.

statutes.name: Japan Act on Protection of Personal Information (APPI)
statutes.description: Japan's comprehensive personal information protection law.
statutes.penalties: Criminal penalties up to 1 year imprisonment or JPY 500,000 fine
statutes.notes: Significantly amended in 2020 to strengthen privacy protections.

statutes.name: South Korea Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA)
statutes.description: South Korea's comprehensive personal information protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to KRW 3% of annual revenue
statutes.notes: One of the strictest privacy laws in Asia.

statutes.name: Brazil General Data Protection Law (LGPD)
statutes.description: Brazil's comprehensive data protection law, heavily inspired by GDPR.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to BRL 50 million or 2% of revenue
statutes.notes: Brazil's answer to GDPR, creating similar privacy rights for Brazilian citizens.

statutes.name: India Personal Data Protection Bill
statutes.description: India's proposed comprehensive data protection legislation (withdrawn in 2022, new version in development).
statutes.notes: Original bill withdrawn in 2022; government working on new comprehensive data protection framework.

statutes.name: Russia Federal Law on Personal Data
statutes.description: Russia's personal data protection law with data localization requirements.
statutes.penalties: Administrative fines and potential service blocking
statutes.notes: Notable for strict data localization requirements.

statutes.name: China Cybersecurity Law
statutes.description: China's comprehensive cybersecurity law establishing cybersecurity requirements.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to CNY 1 million and business suspension
statutes.notes: Establishes broad cybersecurity framework with data localization requirements.

statutes.name: China Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL)
statutes.description: China's comprehensive personal information protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to CNY 50 million or 5% of annual revenue
statutes.notes: China's most comprehensive privacy law, similar in scope to GDPR.

statutes.name: China Data Security Law
statutes.description: China's national data security law establishing data classification and protection requirements.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to CNY 10 million
statutes.notes: Establishes national framework for data security and sovereignty.

statutes.name: Ukraine Law on Personal Data Protection
statutes.description: Ukraine's personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Administrative fines and criminal liability
statutes.notes: Based on EU data protection principles.

statutes.name: Turkey Law on Protection of Personal Data (KVKK)
statutes.description: Turkey's comprehensive personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Administrative fines up to TRY 20 million
statutes.notes: Heavily influenced by EU data protection law.

statutes.name: Israel Privacy Protection Law
statutes.description: Israel's privacy protection law governing personal data.
statutes.penalties: Criminal penalties up to 3 years imprisonment
statutes.notes: EU has recognized Israel as providing adequate level of data protection.

statutes.name: Argentina Personal Data Protection Law
statutes.description: Argentina's personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Administrative fines and criminal penalties
statutes.notes: EU has recognized Argentina as providing adequate level of data protection.

statutes.name: Mexico Federal Law on Protection of Personal Data
statutes.description: Mexico's comprehensive personal data protection law for private sector.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to MXN 32 million
statutes.notes: Applies to private sector; separate law governs public sector.

statutes.name: Colombia Law 1581 on Personal Data Protection
statutes.description: Colombia's personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to COP 2 billion
statutes.notes: Establishes comprehensive data protection framework.

statutes.name: Chile Law 19628 on Protection of Private Life
statutes.description: Chile's privacy law governing personal data processing.
statutes.penalties: Criminal penalties up to 5 years imprisonment
statutes.notes: One of the earlier comprehensive privacy laws in Latin America.

statutes.name: Peru Personal Data Protection Law
statutes.description: Peru's personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Administrative fines up to 100 UIT
statutes.notes: Based on Spanish and European data protection models.

statutes.name: Uruguay Personal Data Protection Law
statutes.description: Uruguay's personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Administrative fines and criminal penalties
statutes.notes: EU has recognized Uruguay as providing adequate level of data protection.

statutes.name: South Africa Protection of Personal Information Act (POPIA)
statutes.description: South Africa's comprehensive personal information protection law.
statutes.penalties: Criminal penalties up to 10 years imprisonment or fines up to ZAR 10 million
statutes.notes: Similar structure to GDPR with African context considerations.

statutes.name: Kenya Data Protection Act
statutes.description: Kenya's comprehensive data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to KES 5 million or 4% of annual turnover
statutes.notes: Modern data protection law influenced by GDPR.

statutes.name: Nigeria Data Protection Regulation (NDPR)
statutes.description: Nigeria's data protection regulation.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to 2% of annual gross revenue or NGN 10 million
statutes.notes: Subsidiary legislation under the Nigeria Information Technology Development Agency Act.

statutes.name: Ghana Data Protection Act
statutes.description: Ghana's data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to GHS 250,000
statutes.notes: One of the first comprehensive data protection laws in West Africa.

statutes.name: Egypt Data Protection Law
statutes.description: Egypt's personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to EGP 1 million and imprisonment
statutes.notes: Part of Egypt's broader digital transformation initiative.

statutes.name: UAE Data Protection Law
statutes.description: UAE's federal personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to AED 3 million
statutes.notes: Modern data protection law aligning UAE with international standards.

statutes.name: Saudi Arabia Personal Data Protection Law (PDPL)
statutes.description: Saudi Arabia's comprehensive personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to SAR 5 million
statutes.notes: Part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 digital transformation.

statutes.name: Thailand Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
statutes.description: Thailand's comprehensive personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to THB 5 million
statutes.notes: GDPR-inspired legislation adapted for Thai context.

statutes.name: Philippines Data Privacy Act
statutes.description: Philippines' comprehensive data privacy law.
statutes.penalties: Imprisonment up to 6 years and fines up to PHP 5 million
statutes.notes: One of the first comprehensive data privacy laws in Southeast Asia.

statutes.name: Indonesia Law on Personal Data Protection
statutes.description: Indonesia's comprehensive personal data protection law.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to IDR 50 billion or 4% of annual revenue
statutes.notes: Modern data protection law bringing Indonesia in line with global standards.

statutes.name: Vietnam Law on Cybersecurity
statutes.description: Vietnam's cybersecurity law with personal data protection provisions.
statutes.penalties: Fines up to VND 200 million for individuals, VND 2 billion for organizations
statutes.notes: Comprehensive cybersecurity law with controversial data localization requirements.

jurisdictions_covered: United States (State - California, Virginia, Colorado, Connecticut, Utah, Illinois, Texas, New York, Massachusetts)
metadata.notes: This comprehensive database covers major computer and data protection laws from 35+ jurisdictions worldwide. Laws are subject to amendments and interpretations that may affect their application. Always consult current legal sources and qualified legal counsel for specific legal advice. The database includes federal laws, state/provincial laws, and major international regulations affecting digital privacy, cybersecurity, and computer use.
